turn.label: Mr. William S. Patterson
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Patterson, did the Guaranty Association file a claim in the proceeding in Indiana, and if so, what did it claim?
Did it file a claim as a contingent creditor?

turn.speaker: william_s_patterson
turn.label: Mr. William S. Patterson
turn.text: It didn't file a claim per se.
What happened is, the original draft of the plan of rehabilitation contemplated certain future recoveries by the rehabilitation court.
I think UNAC had several outstanding suits at that time, so there was a possibility of future recovery.
The rehabilitation proceeding did not... said that any of these future recoveries would go to the policyholder regardless of whether the Guaranty Association had taken their place.
The Guaranty Association came in and said, if we are going to make the policyholder whole, then any of these future benefits should flow back to the Guaranty Association.
That was its only claim in the... in the rehabilitation proceeding.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I ask one other question about the interest?
What is your position as to the proper disposition of that interest today?

turn.speaker: william_s_patterson
turn.label: Mr. William S. Patterson
turn.text: Well, I think if the... the trustee would certainly be empowered to accumulate it for the benefit of the policyholders.
This would be particularly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not what he is empowered to do.
What is your position as to what he should do?

turn.speaker: william_s_patterson
turn.label: Mr. William S. Patterson
turn.text: --I think he should continue to accumulate the interest.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He should accumulate the interest indefinitely, even if there are no claims on the fund.

turn.speaker: william_s_patterson
turn.label: Mr. William S. Patterson
turn.text: If there were no claims, I don't think there is that much justification for doing it, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But then who should get it, in your view?

turn.speaker: william_s_patterson
turn.label: Mr. William S. Patterson
turn.text: --Justice Stevens, if past practice of the department were followed, the interest would begin to be paid again to UNAC.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: To the insurance company.

turn.speaker: william_s_patterson
turn.label: Mr. William S. Patterson
turn.text: In addition to being an income... or a contingent beneficiary, I suppose it would be fair to also characterize UNAC as a contingent income beneficiary as well as a contingent remaindermen in the trust.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Boehm, do you have anything further?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: We don't accept the trust analogy.
It is a pledge.
The asset is UNAC's, always is, always was, still is.

It is pledged to secure against the default, and in the event of default, and only then can the North Carolina Commissioner arrest the interest payments and do the other things that he is purporting to do here.
There is no default.
UNAC and the policyholders reached an agreement whereby UNAC would offer ongoing insurance and the policyholders accepted it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Can't North Carolina tell you to redeposit the $100,000 tomorrow?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Oh, we agree.
It is there.
It is in the deposit, and we can't withdraw it unless we stop writing the insurance on North Carolina insureds, but it is there to secure a future default should we go in the tank again.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I don't see what... it seems to me it is going to be there no matter who wins.
That is what puzzles me.

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Well, they are seeking to liquidate.
The remedy they request is that it be paid over to the Guaranty Association.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And then you would have to make another deposit, if you wanted to write insurance in North Carolina.

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: That is correct, I suppose.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Although the basic--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is what is really at stake, isn't it?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: --Yes.
Yes.
I suppose that is correct.

We haven't anticipated that point, but the logic of what you say seems correct, and we would have to make another deposit, although I expect we would as a practical matter stop writing insurance in that state.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, there was a time when some insurance companies declined to do business in certain states, notably Texas, for reasons of that kind.
Is that not so?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Oh, yes, and that is, again, the basic point of this case from our point of view is that this is an insurance case, and it is a regulated industry that has a state statutory framework that tells the state Commissioner in the state of domicile to do what the Indiana Commissioner did here, and purports to make it stick nationwide.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Boehm, I just didn't really have a clear enough grasp of the facts here.
Is the reason they claim they are entitled to the $100,000 because there has been that much in defaults subsequent to this plan?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: No, there is no claim that UNAC is in default of any post-rehabilitation obligation.
UNAC is honoring its policies as restructured today.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And so they are claiming it on account of default pre-rehabilitation--

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --defaults, but I thought the policyholders had accepted the new plan, so I don't understand what... what are the defaults on which they want this--

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Your confusion is the same as ours, Your Honor.
We think it is as simple as day that the policyholders accepted the restructured policy, we are not in default, and the money is there in its pledged state, if you would, to secure future defaults.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Mr. Boehm, I thought the funds were to be used to pay the increased premium charges that arose out of the rehabilitation.

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: That is going to be paid regardless of the disposition of this case.

As a matter of the North Carolina Guaranty Association's statutory obligation to the policyholders, it has to make up the additional benefits to the policyholders in... UNAC... as between UNAC and the policyholders, the policies are written down.

Now, it is hard to explain this in a few words, because there is disability income insurance, and what in effect they did is change them from non-cancellable, which means you can't raise the premium, to guaranteed renewable, which means we keep insuring these people.
We can't terminate them.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the premiums have gone up.

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: The premiums have gone up, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And isn't the North Carolina Guaranty Association hoping to reach the deposit to repay itself--

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --for the increased cost of the premiums?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Isn't that what we are talking about?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: --Yes, as I understand it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is part of the--
--and the benefits have gone down.
There are two changes, basically.
And so it is a rather complicated actuarial proposition.
Mr. Boehm, don't other states have laws similar to North Carolina's--

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --concerning these deposits?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are they identical in fact?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: I can't represent that, but I believe--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do most states have laws that are similar?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: --Oh, I think so.

It is a question of administrative discretion whether they require a deposit before they will admit a company, but I think most states have a procedure for getting a deposit from a company that they regard as suspect.
And in many cases you end up with the situation we have here, where the amount of the deposit is really miniscule, not enough to warrant the very proceeding that your question focuses on.
Consider what would have happened if every policyholder were perfectly delighted with the plan of rehabilitation and nobody wanted to litigate or anything.

Nonetheless, the Respondent's view would force a mini-liquidation or rehabilitation in eight states where there was nobody who was upset about it, because there would be no way to make the thing a binding adjudication in one form even though nobody was upset about anything.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has the North Carolina court yet held that if you lose in this proceeding, that your opponent is entitled to use the bond to reimburse itself for the increased premium?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Yes, I think that is what the trial court held.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, and you think the appellate court approved of that?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: I think so.
I find the appellate court opinion a little opaque.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, frankly, I didn't get that out of the appellate court opinion.
That is one reason--

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Well, I may be prejudiced... I mean, my view of the appellate court opinion may be colored by what went on in the trial court that I am aware of.
That is what the trial court ordered, and--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Well, was that order affirmed by the appellate court?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: --I think so.
The word "affirmed" ends up at the end of the opinion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that is usually what it means, then, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: I am trying to parse the logic of that opinion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We often say around here it is judgments we review not opinions.

turn.speaker: theodore_r_boehm
turn.label: Mr. Theodore R. Boehm
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
